Looks like i had a few minutes off between action and got a rails error.

Maybe we need to include Steve Chanin's suggestion:
Quick thing with respect to Peer Water exchange.  A couple of days back, I went to check out the site and saw a page that was blank except for the error message “Rails Application (error)”.  Clicking refresh brought up the home page correctly.

I had seen that same thing on some of my sites and discussions with people led me to understand that it is a side effect of the rails application server swapping out of memory due to low use (e.g. No one hitting it for a while) ... Then the first request to come in results in a longer than expected wait (between the web server and rails) which yields that error.  The second hit (e.g. the refresh) works correctly because a side effect of the timeout is a restart of the rails process.

In any case, there is a simple solution ... Setup a background process that hits the rails app every 5 minutes (has to be a dynamic page ... Not a static page).  That will keep the app in memory.

On linux, I just put an entry in the crontab:

    */5 * * * *     curl http://wpp.sapient.com >/dev/null 2>&1

And I haven’t seen the problem since.

column1: Put PWX icon in url bar
column2:
To put an icon in the URL space of one of your own pages, make a very small image. By very small, it should be 16 X 16 pixels and it should only use 16 or 8 colors. The image should be a gif and it should be very basic or it'll be too small to look like anything. Once you have your image the way you want it, rename it to have the extension .ico instead of .gif. It needs to have the .ico extension to be viewed as an icon, and it needs to be an icon for this to work.

Then, use this code inbetween the HEAD tags of the page:

< link REL="shortcut icon" type="image/x-icon" HREF="/path_to_image/pwxdrop-tiny.ico" >

Check your page and you now have an icon. If you want the image to appear in someone's Internet Explorer Favorites links as an image, just name your image favicon.ico and it will work.

if a review phase ends, the reviewer should not be able to review the app anymore.

column1: Put applications on the map
column2:
We need to add 2 fields: longitude and latitude to the application.
This should be on the step one, near the geography fields.

For now, we can have a back door into entering the data.


The map should display all active and approved applications (until they get converted to a project - what about program-funding?)) with a new icon (to be supplied later). Upon clicking: a bubble will pop up with:

 1 - Country
 2 - Name of project
 3 - Short description
 4 - Applicant name
 5 - Link to the application form.

If you are logged in, you can control appropriate:
  - edit/withdraw if you are applicant/admin, 
  - ratings if you are reviewer/applicant/admin/other(works now!)

For now, we will keep it open, so that non-logged in users can browse the application and the forum.

We should keep the option of restricting them to the map (no clickable link) in case we decide that in the future.

column1: Finer control of icons on the map
column2:
Each funding round should have icons that are distinct.
When a cycle is created the icons residing in a folder will be available for the admin to select for each phase in the cycle:

1/ submission phase
2/ peer review phase
3/ (Optional) limbo phase between application and project: granted/funded/accepted but projects not created
   this might be tricky for multi-project funding where outstanding funds are still available but some projects have been started
4/ project implementation phase
5/ (Options) project completed

Each phase, the icon can be selected from a list of all the icons in a special directory which can been updated easily (add new icon files).

It will be the responsibility of the admin to add new icons to the appropriate folder on the server and ensure their size, format, etc. matches the requirements. We should also specify the maximum size for our application and whether we recommend shadows or not.

column12:

By "extended funding phase" i meant that we end the funding phase when the cycle ends. However, the projects are often in limbo for months, until they kick off (or the data on the kickoff is entered).

There can be a large gap between the application and the project and our map will not show it. Once the app is funded, the application icon is off the map. But until the project is kicked off, the project icon does not appear.

For multi-project this 'sitting funds' may last a long time; until they are all used up.

My comment was not to change cycle creation as much as to capture the time in between funding of an app and the project creation.

This is an optional request and also a discussion of any ideas to put pressure on the implementers to 'create' the project. Maybe use a '?' as an icon that reflects on the implementer (near their home icon).

column1: Create a peer review process for referring new members to PWX
column2:
I
Members should be able to refer prospective members.

1. be able submit info: person name, org name, email

2. <optional> admin gets that and accepts referral <optional>

4. prospective fills out org info and submits

5. admin is notified

6. admin is able to send the org info out to review

    1. org info (similar to app info)
    2. q&a
    3. review (similar to app review, but different and will be described in new tix)
    4. admin (for sending to review, setting deadline, etc.)

7. unlike a funding cycle, there will be deadline associated with this

8. at end of review admin can defer, accept, reject prospective
 - accepted -> org status becomes one of regular (admin sets)
 - rejected -> org status becomes disabled
 - deferred -> org status becomes disabled

9. historical info is retained: 
 - org referral history
 - org referee
